Tammo Freese wrote:

>  > When I started using jMock, I much preferred it, because:
>  >
>  > 1. It has direct support for fakes/stubs.
> 
> EasyMock 1 had default return values/throwables for that,
> EasyMock 2 has stub return values/throwables for that.

So jMock > EasyMock1, but jMock ~ EasyMock2 with regard to support for 
fakes.

>  > 2. It makes ignoring method parameters easy.
> 
> I agree, This was a major pain in EasyMock 1.
> The rationale behind this was that I found no way to make
> this refactoring-safe (reordering parameter refactorings should
> not break the test). In EasyMock 2, matchers can be defined
> directly in the method calls, allowing to ignore arguments,
> match only parts of an argument, and so on.
> You may even define your own matchers.

That sounds like an improvement. Since jMock's comparative 
refactoring-unfriendliness is not a big cost for me, I'm not moved to 
switch to EasyMock2.

>  > 3. Its support for complex parameter, method or invocation matching is
>  > great.
> 
> EasyMock 2 has much better support for that. Argument matchers
> are in my opinion better. Inter-mock dependencies can be defined.

I would have to look at this.

>  > If there is ever a 2nd edition of _JUnit Recipes_, I will replace all
>  > the EasyMock example code with jMock.
> 
> As the author of EasyMock, I am sad to hear that.
> Can you elaborate which features are missing in
> EasyMock 2 that are so crucial that you consider switching?

It's not a question of what's missing in EasyMock2. The reason is that 
since 2003, I've been using jMock exclusively as my dynamic mock objects 
library, so that's what I know best. If I get on a project where they 
already use EasyMock2, I'm sure I'd get used to it quickly and would 
probably enjoy it.

>  > The people who don't like jMock often say it's because declaring the
>  > method names as strings makes refactoring more error-prone. That might
>  > be the case, but I have never felt pain as a result of it.
> 
> It's not only a problem when renaming methods.
> 
> Reordering, adding, or removing parameters all break tests at runtime,
> and you have to adapt them manually to the new situation.
> Tests using EasyMock work after reordering and removing
> parameters, and after adding parameters if no matchers were used.

See above: you're right, but I find the cost to be low.

> And there is also the issue of code completion when defining expectations.
> With JMock, it does not work, you have to rely on text completion features.
> With EasyMock, it works like a charm.

I do admit that this is a shortcoming, but I don't find that annoying 
when I use jMock. In fact, in an odd way, if I find I really want code 
completion when defining fakes or expectations, then perhaps my 
interface is too complex. :)

Perhaps.

Tammo, don't get me wrong: I really appreciate what EasyMock 1 did for 
me for 2 solid years, and EasyMock 1 is immortalized in _JUnit Recipes_. 
It's just that I preferred jMock 1.0 to EasyMock 1, and I haven't had 
the need to leave jMock yet. EasyMock 2 doesn't pull me and jMock 1.x 
doesn't push me away.

Take care.
